prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: IKTauB7
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Water masers and continuum, B7 IK Tau

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Sensitivity and resolution
The maser lines are likely to have complex spectra (individual feature FWHM ~1-2 km/s) with peaks up to tens or hundreds Jy and we want to model the kinematics on the scale of 5-15-mas clumps, requiring SNR 25-8. This will be achieved for 1.7-Jy 325-GHz masers (likely to be located further out in larger clumps) and for 0.8-Jy 321-GHz masers in the smallest clumps (owing to the greater sensitivity). High spectral and spatial resolution is also needed to constrain maser propagation models. If the maser peaks are very bright they may be dynamic-range limited but SNR of several hundred or more is possible and the resulting position accuracy is of great importance for testing maser beaming models. We ask for a sensitivity of 0.2 Jy per 70.557 kHz channel in quiet parts of the spw around the 325 GHz line.
We expect to get ~0.5 mJy sensitivity for line-free continuum as the atmosphere improves away from the representative frequency. This should allow detailed imaging of extended dust emission as well as using the central star (15-40 mJy) for astrometric registration with Band 6 and other data.
Observing strategy
We have chosen to place additional lower-resolution spectral windows close to the maser lines, in order to ensure good bandpass calibration and continuum subtraction. The 13CS line may be detected (predicted peak 220 mJy/km/s). We are aware that the 325-GHz spectral region is affected by the atmosphere but Cycle 0 and CSV results show that the sensitivities given in the Calculator and reasonable astrometry can be achieved providing the current bandpass correction best practices are followed, especially as both the maser lines and stellar continuum are likely to be bright enough for self-calibration. The additional fairly high-resolution spectral windows placed on SiO and CS isotopologues will serve as checks for bandpass stability even if the thermal lines require broader channels for detection.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: WHyaB7
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Water masers and continuum, B7 W Hya

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Sensitivity and resolution
The maser lines are likely to have complex spectra (individual feature FWHM ~1-2 km/s) with peaks up to tens or hundreds Jy and we want to model the kinematics on the scale of 5-15-mas clumps, requiring SNR 25-8. This will be achieved for 1.7-Jy 325-GHz masers (likely to be located further out in larger clumps) and for 0.8-Jy 321-GHz masers in the smallest clumps (owing to the greater sensitivity). High spectral and spatial resolution is also needed to constrain maser propagation models. If the maser peaks are very bright they may be dynamic-range limited but SNR of several hundred or more is possible and the resulting position accuracy is of great importance for testing maser beaming models. We ask for a sensitivity of 0.2 Jy per 70.557 kHz channel in quiet parts of the spw around the 325 GHz line.
We expect to get ~0.5 mJy sensitivity for line-free continuum as the atmosphere improves away from the representative frequency. This should allow detailed imaging of extended dust emission as well as using the central star (~335 mJy) for astrometric registration with Band 6 and other data.
Observing strategy
We have chosen to place additional lower-resolution spectral windows close to the maser lines, in order to ensure good bandpass calibration and continuum subtraction. We are aware that the 325-GHz spectral region is affected by the atmosphere but Cycle 0 and CSV results show that the sensitivities given in the Calculator and reasonable astrometry can be achieved providing the current bandpass correction best practices are followed, especially as both the maser lines and stellar continuum are likely to be bright enough for self-calibration. The additional fairly high-resolution spectral windows placed on SiO and CS isotopologues will serve as checks for bandpass stability even if the thermal lines require broader channels for detection.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: IKTauB6
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Water masers and continuum, B6 IK Tau

prj:VisitConstraint.prj:note: It would be helpful but not essential if the Band

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Sensitivity and resolution
We hope to detect a significant number of SiO and 233-GHz H2O maser components at >500 mJy, sufficient SNR to locate them to within the anticipated clump size ~5 mas within a few stellar radii. Each transition will have considerable substructure; individual maser features have line widths ~1-3 km/s. Fainter emission will be located with enough precision to confirm that it is located within the 60-mas dust formation radius. High spectral and spatial resolution is also needed to constrain maser models. We ask for a sensitivity of 0.015 Jy per 70.557 kHz channel.
We expect to get ~0.1 mJy sensitivity for line-free continuum. This should allow detailed imaging of extended dust emission as well as using the central star (~8-15 mJy) for astrometric registration with Band 7 and other data. We want to observe all spw in FDM in order to detect thermal lines and to simplify fitting a bandpass across all spw.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: WHyaB6
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Water masers and continuum, B6 W Hya

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Sensitivity and resolution
We hope to detect a significant number of SiO and 233-GHz H2O maser components at >500 mJy, sufficient SNR to locate them to within the anticipated clump size ~5 mas within a few stellar radii. Each transition will have considerable substructure; individual maser features have line widths ~1-3 km/s. Fainter emission will be located with enough precision to confirm that it is located within the 60-mas dust formation radius. High spectral and spatial resolution is also needed to constrain maser models. We ask for a sensitivity of 0.015 Jy per 70.557 kHz channel.
We expect to get ~0.1 mJy sensitivity for line-free continuum. This should allow detailed imaging of extended dust emission as well as using the central star (~225 mJy) for astrometric registration with Band 7 and other data. We want to observe all spw in FDM in order to detect thermal lines and to simplify fitting a bandpass across all spw.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: After stars ~1-few Msun leave the main sequence they progress onto the Asymptotic Giant Branch (AGB), where they cool, swell up and develop thick, dusty winds. The mass loss mechanism, particularly from O-rich stars, is not fully understood. How does dust formation affect the kinematics and clumping scales? What allows the complex infall/outflow within a few stellar radii to metamorphose into a wind which is steadily radially accelerating? ALMA observations of 325-, 321- and 233-GHz H2O masers in early and late AGB stars W Hya and IK Tau will provide the first-ever spatially and spectrally resolved images of lines spanning both sides of the dust formation zone, showing how the kinematics and excitation conditions change. The inner radius of bulk dust formation will be resolved and thermal lines thought to be shock tracers could be detected. This will clarify the roles of stellar pulsations and radiation pressure on dust in driving the wind.
